nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) as advanced by Peters is pseudoscience because it has not produced falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
Peters and collaborators claim mainstream economic theory is flawed and propose 'ergodicity economics' as a conceptually clearer alternative
Ergodicity economics prescribes growth rate optimization: maximize the long-run geometric average growth rate of wealth

Two-asset continuous-time portfolio model: risky asset follows geometric Brownian motion with drift mu and volatility sigma, safe asset yields risk-free rate r, fixed continuously rebalanced portfolio fraction theta; terminal wealth WT is lognormal
Applying EE objective (maximize long-run log growth) to the model yields optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r) / sigma^2
Expected utility theory (EUT) with CRRA utility yields objective V(theta)= r + (mu - r)theta - (1/2) gamma sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal theta = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma^2)
EE and EUT make identical predictions for the portfolio problem when relative risk aversion gamma equals one (log utility)

The portfolio model provides a testable implication: in principle observe mu, r, sigma and investors' chosen theta to check EE prediction theta = (mu - r)/sigma^2, and EUT proportionality to (mu - r)/sigma^2
EE has so far produced few nontrivial testable implications or extensions (e.g., multi-period consumption-investment problems) despite claims of generality, limiting falsifiability in practice

EE exhibits multiple Wikipedia-listed indicators of pseudoscience: vague or exaggerated claims, improper evidence use, lack of expert review, absence of progress, personalization, and misleading language

Concrete examples supporting the indicators: grandiose unresolved claims in publications, reliance on limited or criticized experimental citations, most papers not reviewed by economists, repeated citation of older results, personalized rhetoric, and ambiguous terminology in abstracts

Conclusion: Given the limited falsifiable implications and multiple indicators of pseudoscience, EE should be viewed skeptically and not treated as established scientific theory until it produces clear, testable predictions and engages disciplinary peer review
